meanings.def: belonging to somebody; relating to somebody
examples: the love of a mother for her child
Can't you throw out that old bike of Tommy's?

meanings.def: belonging to something; being part of something; relating to something
coming from a particular background or living in a place
used to say what somebody/something is, consists of or contains
used with measurements and expressions of time, age, etc.
examples: (old-fashioned) We would often have a walk of an evening.

meanings.def: used to show somebody/something belongs to a group, often after some, a few, etc.
examples: the most famous of all the stars

meanings.def: used to show the position of something/somebody in space or time
examples: at the time of the revolution
(North American English) at a quarter of eleven tonight (= 10.45 p.m.)

meanings.def: used after nouns formed from verbs. The noun after ‘of’ can be either the object or the subject of the action.
examples: the arrival of the police (= they arrive)
criticism of the police (= they are criticized)

meanings.def: used after some verbs before mentioning somebody/something involved in the action
examples: He was cleared of all blame.
Think of a number, any number.

meanings.def: used after some adjectives before mentioning somebody/something that a feeling relates to
used to give your opinion of somebody’s behaviour
examples: It was kind of you to offer.

meanings.def: used when one noun describes a second one
examples: Where's that idiot of a boy (= the boy that you think is stupid)?

meanings.def: used before a noun to say that something is very surprising
examples: I'm surprised that you of all people should say that.

idioms.def: used before a noun to say that something is very surprising
examples: I'm surprised that you of all people should say that.
